title: inn2: Posting via inews causes Perl error

sentences.text: Since I upgraded to Perl 5.14.2, I get the following errors when using mailagent's POST command (which calls "inews -h" to inject
Remote error: Bizarre copy of UNKNOWN.
There must be something wrong with one of the Perl scripts that INN calls.
Versions of packages inn2 depends on:
ii  cron                    3.0pl1-86        management of regular background p ii  inn2-inews              2.5.2-2          NNTP client news injector, from In
ii  libc6                   2.13-10          Embedded GNU C Library: Shared lib
ii  libdb5.1                5.1.25-11        Berkeley v5.1 Database Libraries [
ii  libmime-tools-perl      5.428-1          Perl5 modules for MIME-compliant m
ii  libpam0g                1.1.1-3          Pluggable Authentication Modules l
ii  perl                    5.14.2-6         Larry Wall's Practical Extraction
ii  procps                  1:3.2.8-1        /proc file system utilities ii  sendmail-bin [mail-tran 8.14.3-1         powerful, efficient, and scalable
ii  time                    1.7-21           The GNU time program for measuring ii  zlib1g                  1:1.2.3.3.dfsg-5 compression library - runtime

ii  gnupg                 1.4.6-2.2          GNU privacy guard - a free PGP rep ii  libcomerr2            1.40.8-2           common error description library pn  libgd-gd2-noxpm-perl  <none>             (no description available)
ii  libkrb5-3             1.8.3+dfsg~beta1-1 MIT Kerberos runtime libraries
ii  wget                  1.8.2-5            retrieves files from the web
> Since I upgraded to Perl 5.14.2, I get the following errors when > using mailagent's POST command (which calls "inews -h" to inject
> Remote error: Bizarre copy of UNKNOWN.
> There must be something wrong with one of the Perl scripts that INN > calls.
Does the error happen every time you POST a message via mailagent?
Does the error happen if you directly use "inews -h"?
(Just pipe the  contents of an article into its standard input.)
And, more importantly (probably the first test to run), does the error  happen after deactivating Perl in INN?
Just execute with the news user:
and try to POST a message via mailagent.
Do not forget to reactivate  Perl afterwards, with:
Et puis, toi tu penses, moi je suis.
Yes, the error is logged in mailagent's ".bak" file, where plain stderr messages go.
> Does the error happen every time you POST a message via mailagent?
> Does the error happen if you directly use "inews -h"?
(Just pipe the  > contents of an article into its standard input.)
I don't use the original inews that comes with INN2, but the version I compiled from "trn".
The reason being that the trn-inews is not so picky about how much text is quoted as opposed to how much text is added...
However, both commands return the same error:
Remote error: Bizarre copy of UNKNOWN.
(that's the exact text that goes into mailagent's error file).
inews: cannot send article to server: Bizarre copy of UNKNOWN.
inews: warning: server did not reply to quit: Connection reset by peer
> And, more importantly (probably the first test to run), does the error  > happen after deactivating Perl in INN?
Just execute with the news user:
> and try to POST a message via mailagent.
Do not forget to reactivate Perl  > afterwards, with:
I did not know about this INN option, but it has no impact.
The errors are the same whether I say "perl n" or "perl y".
Please let me know how I can further diagnose what's happening.
> 	inews: cannot send article to server: Bizarre copy of UNKNOWN.
> 	inews: warning: server did not reply to quit: Connection reset by peer
"cannot send article to server" is returned when inews receive an NNTP response code different from 240 (= POST OK) after having sent the article.
"Bizarre copy of UNKOWN" seems to be the actual response code!
nnrpd has closed the connection itself, probably encountering an internal error.
A proper answer would for instance be:
inews: cannot send article to server: 441 No valid newsgroups in "trigo.pouet"
First question:  is there a Newsgroups: line mentioned in your ~/tmp/article file?
If not, please add one and test again.
(I have just spotted a bug in INN 2.5.2+20110413, that is not in INN 2.5.2.)
If you already see a Newsgroups: header field, then:
Do you have Perl hooks for nnrpd authentication?
Could you try to deactivate them if it is the case?
Do you manage to post to your nnprd via another tool than inews?
Could you try to write the contents of your ~/tmp/article file in an NNTP session?
Just send "MODE READER", "POST", copy/paste your article and add a final dot.
200 news.trigofacile.com InterNetNews server INN 2.6.0 (20111015 prerelease) ready (transit mode)
200 news.trigofacile.com InterNetNews NNRP server INN 2.6.0 (20111015 prerelease) ready (posting ok)
> I did not know about this INN option, but it has no impact.
The errors > are the same whether I say "perl n" or "perl y".
Then it means that Perl used by innd is not the culprit.
Yet, I am still puzzled because Perl hooks are only for authentication.
When you POST, authentication has already been done.
> Please let me know how I can further diagnose what's happening.
Could there be something related to:
Je viens de rencontrer Isocle : il a une ide pour un nouveau
: First question:  is there a Newsgroups: line mentioned in your ~/tmp/article : file?
If not, please add one and test again.
: (I have just spotted a bug in INN 2.5.2+20110413, that is not in INN 2.5.2.)
Yes, there is a Newsgroups line in my ~/tmp/article file.
: If you already see a Newsgroups: header field, then:
: Do you have Perl hooks for nnrpd authentication?
: Could you try to deactivate them if it is the case?
I don't have any such files in /etc/news.
: Do you manage to post to your nnprd via another tool than inews?
Here's the result of a direct NNTP post:
200 tours.ram.loc InterNetNews server INN 2.5.3 (20110413 snapshot) ready (transit mode)
200 tours.ram.loc InterNetNews NNRP server INN 2.5.3 (20110413 snapshot) ready (posting ok)
where I feed my mailing lists ("ml.") through mailagent's POST command.
I know that the "Bizarre copy of UNKNOWN" message comes from Perl (long perl experience) but maybe this wording has been reused in INN for non-perl code?
> 200 tours.ram.loc InterNetNews server INN 2.5.3 (20110413 snapshot) ready (transit mode)
> 200 tours.ram.loc InterNetNews NNRP server INN 2.5.3 (20110413 snapshot) ready (posting ok)
It looks as though it were an error related to IHAVE, answered by innd via nnrpd.
Could you send the following example (with an additional
Path: header field) via IHAVE, without MODE READER?
200 tours.ram.loc InterNetNews server INN 2.5.3 (20110413 snapshot) ready (transit mode)
> I know that the "Bizarre copy of UNKNOWN" message comes from Perl (long perl > experience) but maybe this wording has been reused in INN for non-perl code?
As far as I can see, "Bizarre" is a word without any occurrence in the whole INN source code.
If you think this problem could come from the Perl stack, is it possible for you to patch the version of INN you are currently running, with the following changes committed in July 2011?
I re-organized the calls of the ENTER-SAVETMPS-PUSHMARK-PUTBACK and SPAGAIN-PUTBACK-FREETMPS-LEAVE macros:
*Maybe* it fixes the issue you are facing.
If patching your INN is not straight-forward, perhaps Marco -- if he has time -- could generate (for you only, or also uploaded to sid) a Debian package from the current STABLE repository.
La femme est beaucoup plus porte que l'homme aux actes imprudents
: It looks as though it were an error related to IHAVE, answered : by innd via nnrpd.
: Could you send the following example (with an additional
: Path: header field) via IHAVE, without MODE READER?
200 tours.ram.loc InterNetNews server INN 2.5.3 (20110413 snapshot) ready (transit mode)
Looks like you have a lead now to further investigate...
Let me know if I can help you further narrow down the problem.
So the problem seems located to nnrpd.
> : Do you have Perl hooks for nnrpd authentication?
> : Could you try to deactivate them if it is the case?
> I don't have any such files in /etc/news.
In your /etc/news/readers.conf file (or another name if you have changed the default configuration), do you have active lines for perl_auth and  perl_access?
If that is the case, they are used.
There is also filter_nnrpd.pl, besides the two for authentication.
Could you please send the lines in /var/log/news/news.notice  corresponding to your attempt to post via inews this morning?
We continued in private to investigate the issue and, after having rebuilt nnrpd so as to allow gdb to be useful, Raphal found out the source of the error.
In nnrpd/post.c during ARTpost(), there is a call to an XS Perl function HandleHeaders():
(modswitch is false, because the SvTRUE condition is not executed.)
nnrpd/perl.c, line 179 for the Debian package.
Has someone an idea of what is going on in recent Perl versions?
I see that Marco already experienced that with INN 1.x:
but there were no replies to his thread.
Is the solution of "body = &PL_sv_undef" working fine?
Another question:  isn't there a way not to cause nnrpd to die when such an error occurs in XS code?
The right behaviour would be to return:
and to go on the NNTP session.
Oui, je ne peux pas payer mon ardoise.
On Sun, Jan 15, 2012 at 12:13:21PM +0100, Julien LIE wrote:
> nnrpd/perl.c, line 179 for the Debian package.
> Has someone an idea of what is going on in recent Perl versions?
> I see that Marco already experienced that with INN 1.x:
> but there were no replies to his thread.
> Is the solution of "body = &PL_sv_undef" working fine?
at least #649759 suggests this might be related to not using all the compilation flags from ExtUtils::Embed, '-D_LARGEFILE_SOURCE
-D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64' in particular. Indeed, I see the inn2 'configure' script chops those away.
As of Perl 5.14.0, compiling without those flags on 32-bit
architectures and then linking against libperl apparently creates a binary incompatibility, manifesting in strange errors such as the one discussed here.
> at least #649759 suggests this might be related to not using all > the compilation flags from ExtUtils::Embed, '-D_LARGEFILE_SOURCE > -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64' in particular.
I removed the flags because generally enabling LFS would create an inn package which cannot read the on-disk data written by the precedent release, and for which there is no conversion tool.
So I need to find out if the internal INN ABI between the perl bits and  the rest of the program depends on LFS.
> > at least #649759 suggests this might be related to not using all > > the compilation flags from ExtUtils::Embed, '-D_LARGEFILE_SOURCE
> I removed the flags because generally enabling LFS would create an inn > package which cannot read the on-disk data written by the precedent > release, and for which there is no conversion tool.
> So I need to find out if the internal INN ABI between the perl bits and  > the rest of the program depends on LFS.
This is not going to be easy.
Are you totally sure that there is no  other option than building with LFS all code which includes perl  headers?
On Sun, Feb 19, 2012 at 04:00:42AM +0100, Marco d'Itri wrote:
> > > at least #649759 suggests this might be related to not using all > > > the compilation flags from ExtUtils::Embed, '-D_LARGEFILE_SOURCE

> > I removed the flags because generally enabling LFS would create an inn > > package which cannot read the on-disk data written by the precedent > > release, and for which there is no conversion tool.
> > So I need to find out if the internal INN ABI between the perl bits and  > > the rest of the program depends on LFS.
> This is not going to be easy.
Are you totally sure that there is no  > other option than building with LFS all code which includes perl  > headers?
At least all code that accesses a PerlInterpreter struct, AFAICS.
The problem is that the PerlInterpreter struct has two members of type "Stat_t" (see intrpvar.h) , which is a "struct stat" on unix and so varies in size depending on the LFS flags.
All the later interpreter specific variables in the struct are accessed at a wrong offset if those flags don't match the ones libperl was built with.
'PL_sv_undef' is one of these variables, and the 'Bizarre copy of unknown' error comes from a sanity check inside the sv_setsv() call because the wrong PL_sv_undef doesn't make any sense.
I guess you could work around that sanity check with the 'body = &PL_sv_undef' trick, but I'd expect other problems later.
On Fri, 13 Jan 2012 21:15:07 +0100, Raphael Manfredi wrote:
> Since I upgraded to Perl 5.14.2, I get the following errors when > using mailagent's POST command (which calls "inews -h" to inject
We stumbled over the same bug with mailman and inn2.
A quick workaround seems to be to put
in all (or the relevant) access groups in /etc/news/readers.conf.
It least it works for us :)
